t: Exodus 15
The Song of Moses
Then*p Moses and the people of Israel sang this song to the Lord,*s saying, “I*pn will sing to the Lord,*s for he has triumphed gloriously; the*ld horse and his rider he has thrown into the sea.
The*ln Lord*s is my strength and my song, and*ld he has become my salvation; this*ln is my God, and I will praise him, my*ld father’s God, and I will exalt him.
The*ln Lord*s is a man of war; the*ld Lord*s is his name.
“Pharaoh’s*pn chariots and his host he cast into the sea, and*ld his chosen officers were sunk in the Red Sea.
The*ln floods covered them; they*ld went down into the depths like a stone.
Your*ln right hand, O Lord,*s glorious in power, your*ld right hand, O Lord,*s shatters the enemy.
In*ln the greatness of your majesty you overthrow your adversaries; you*ld send out your fury; it consumes them like stubble.
At*ln the blast of your nostrils the waters piled up; the*ld floods stood up in a heap; the*ld deeps congealed in the heart of the sea.
The*ln enemy said, ‘I will pursue, I will overtake, I*ld will divide the spoil, my desire shall have its fill of them. I*ld will draw my sword; my hand shall destroy them.’
You*ln blew with your wind; the sea covered them; they*ld sank like lead in the mighty waters.
“Who*pn is like you, O Lord,*s among the gods? Who*ld is like you, majestic in holiness, awesome*ld in glorious deeds, doing wonders?
You*ln stretched out your right hand; the*ld earth swallowed them.
“You*pn have led in your steadfast love the people whom you have redeemed; you*ld have guided them by your strength to your holy abode.
The*ln peoples have heard; they tremble; pangs*ld have seized the inhabitants of Philistia.
Now*ln are the chiefs of Edom dismayed; trembling*ld seizes the leaders of Moab; all*ld the inhabitants of Canaan have melted away.
Terror*ln and dread fall upon them; because*ld of the greatness of your arm, they are still as a stone, till*ln your people, O Lord,*s pass by, till*ld the people pass by whom you have purchased.
You*ln will bring them in and plant them on your own mountain, the*ld place, O Lord,*s which you have made for your abode, the*ld sanctuary, O Lord, which your hands have established.
The*ln Lord*s will reign forever and ever.”

For*p when the horses of Pharaoh with his chariots and his horsemen went into the sea, the Lord*s brought back the waters of the sea upon them, but the people of Israel walked on dry ground in the midst of the sea.
Then Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a tambourine in her hand, and all the women went out after her with tambourines and dancing.
And Miriam sang to them: “Sing*pn to the Lord,*s for he has triumphed gloriously; the*ln horse and his rider he has thrown into the sea.”
Bitter Water Made Sweet
Then*p Moses made Israel set out from the Red Sea, and they went into the wilderness of Shur. They went three days in the wilderness and found no water.
When they came to Marah, they could not drink the water of Marah because it was bitter; therefore it was named Marah.
And the people grumbled against Moses, saying, “What shall we drink?”

And he cried to the Lord,*s and the Lord*s showed him a log, and he threw it into the water, and the water became sweet. There*p the Lord*s made for them a statute and a rule, and there he tested them,

saying, “If you will diligently listen to the voice of the Lord*s your God, and do that which is right in his eyes, and give ear to his commandments and keep all his statutes, I will put none of the diseases on you that I put on the Egyptians, for I am the Lord,*s your healer.”
Then*p they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they encamped there by the water.
